awd_titl_txt: EAGER- Developing Technologies in Air-Quality Monitoring for Environmentally Engaged and Empowered Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
1645287
Khan

The development and applications of low-cost, portable air-quality sensors to measure gases and particulate pollutants has grown significantly in the past several years. This need is further elevated by poor and deteriorating air quality and related health concerns experienced in urban regions throughout the world, in both the developed and developing countries. This EAGER proposal aims at developing a citizen science program to study the impact of air-pollution, and, a basic understating of factors that influence local and regional air-quality by broad dissemination of sensor technology to the local communities and to the general public. A novel aspect of this air monitoring citizens science program is that it brings together various organizations, communities with diverse background of participants and volunteers.

Atmospheric carbon dioxide, methane, and water vapor are the three of the most important greenhouse gases with impact on the radiative forcing on earth with diverse sources of emissions. Among several of the anthropogenic sources of emissions, a few are: fossil fuel combustion, agricultural soil management, landfills, and fugitive emissions from natural gas. Therefore, as a part of technological development part of this project the PI will design and develop a low-cost, portable, highly precise and user-friendly sensor porotypes to simultaneously measure carbon dioxide, methane, carbon monoxide and water vapor. There are two goals of this program: 1. design and develop technologies that enable low-cost and user-friendly operation of air-quality monitoring sensors, and, 2. develop a comprehensive program to enhance environmental awareness by infusing these technologies to key stakeholders by partnering with local schools, environmental agencies and organizations in the state of Delaware. This air monitoring citizen science program involves several stakeholders and participants from local environmental agencies, local organizations, schools, hospitals and health services in the state of Delaware. The program will empower communities towards better understanding of tools and technologies of monitoring systems, basis understanding of air quality and pollution, and its local and global impact. Several components of citizens air monitoring program will integrate into current programs from partner organizations which includes school rain garden project, green buildings, vehicle ant-idling campaigns and awareness campaigns of impact of air quality on children?s health. Finally, the program will greatly enhance capacity and capabilities of Delaware State University, an HBCU institution, by developing innovative sensing technologies for low-cost, portable next-generation air monitoring sensors.

por.por_cntn:
The project has two major goals: first, design and develop technologies that enable low-cost and user-friendly operation of air-quality monitoring and, second, develop a comprehensive program to enhance environmental awareness by infusing these technologies to key stakeholders by partnering with local schools, environmental agencies in the state of Delaware. The citizen’s science project award enabled portable, highly sensitive and accurate technologies for air-quality monitoring. The project also addressed new and emerging need for low-cost technologies for wide area mapping and real-time analysis of State’s air-quality.  Field-based prototypes of methane, carbon dioxide sensors were developed from this project to identify and quantify key emissions hotspots in the State of Delaware.  Several air-quality monitoring field campaigns were conducted, and sensors were deployed at multiple sites across the State in order to better understand distribution and characteristics of sources. The project involved students from Delaware State University (DSU) an 1890 land-grant HBCU institution, local high-schools, Delaware Natural Resources and Environmental Commission (DNREC) and high school educators. The project also enabled new collaborations resulting in peer-reviewed publications, multidisciplinary collaborative research proposals and student development and science education.

Intellectual Merit: Laser-based technologies are ideal for broad spectrum of applications for detection of greenhouse gases and precision sensing of the environment. These novel technologies are generally low-power, lightweight, portable, and can be deployed on ubiquitous platforms, including residential, urban or agricultural, and industrial locations. In this project we developed two field-deployable prototypes of methane and carbon dioxide using infrared lasers and achieved required sensitivity and precision for atmospheric sensing. Through multiple field campaigns at selected (e.g., poultry, landfills and other industrial) sites in the State, we primarily focused on validating methane and carbon dioxide in-situ data with satellite observations. In addition, we also correlated in-situ methane emissions with satellite observational data of other tracers of industrial emissions like nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide. Finally, from the satellite observational data from March 2020 to July 2020, we also evaluated impact of COVID-19 restrictions on industrial activity in the State and overall impact on industrial emissions. The project enabled technological goals through investments in building new laser technologies, translating them from laboratory to field and validating science and new data on previously unknown hotspots in the State of Delaware.

Broader Impacts: The outcomes of the project address key societal challenges pertaining to the impact of climate change, indoor and outdoor pollution on communities. This project involved undergraduate and graduate research, innovation and education connected with citizen’s science to prepare students for next-generation STEM workforce. Currently, there is very limited participation of minorities in the academic or professional career path to environmental engineering, especially, in areas of research and development.   Therefore, major thrust of this research and innovation project was to engage undergraduate students at DSU to become an integral part of projects through project teams. Over the period of three years, we were able to train over 20 undergraduate students and three graduate students in fields of instruments design, opto-mechanics, laser sensing, data analysis and field deployments. Integration of hands-on projects and team building has been a proven methodology to engage students in STEM disciplines. This effectively promotes basic understanding and scientific quest to practical realization. The knowledge based developed from this research was disseminated to the scientific community through conference presentation, peer-reviewed journal publications and through outreach events in the local community. The project was truly multidisciplinary in nature as it integrates aspects of electrical and environmental engineering through novel sensing technologies, basic understating of fate and transport of chemicals and pollutants in the atmosphere. Finally, the project had significant impact on the university by enhancing capacity, capabilities and forging new training and collaborative programs at DSU.
